title: How the Los Angeles Lakers Transformed Into a True Title Contender Ahead of the Playoffs | NBA News - The Times of India
text: The Los Angeles Lakers have turned their season around in a remarkable way. While they were never below .500, their 22-18 record through 40 games suggested they were far from title contenders. They had a negative point differential (-2.6 per game) and ranked 12th in the Western Conference in that metric. However, the Lakers have flipped the script since then, going 20-7 in their last 27 games and outscoring opponents by 8.3 points per 100 possessions. Only three teams have posted a better record in that span, and just two have been statistically superior. A major part of their resurgence has been the acquisition of Luka Doncic, who has given the Lakers a new offensive dimension. But beyond Doncic, defensive improvements, roster depth, and elite playmaking have made Los Angeles a serious title threat. Let’s take a closer look at the four biggest reasons behind their transformation.4 Reasons That Make the Los Angeles Lakers a Valid Title Contender in 2025 1. Defensive Improvement Inside and Out 119229837The Los Angeles Lakers’ improvement has come on both ends of the floor, but the most significant jump has been on defense. Over the last two months, they have ranked second in defensive rating, a remarkable leap from their previous ranking of 24th. Key Defensive Stats Timeframe W L PCT OffRtg (Rank) DefRtg (Rank) NetRtg (Rank) Through Jan. 19 22 18 0.550 112.8 (13th) 115.7 (24th) -2.9 (21st) Since Jan. 20 20 7 0.741 117.0 (7th) 108.7 (2nd) +8.3 (3rd) Difference +0.191 +4.2 -7.0 +11.2 The improvement is particularly impressive given the rising league-wide offensive efficiency, which has jumped from 112.9 points per 100 possessions through January to 114.7 in February and March.Defensive Changes made by the Lakers:Opponent Shot Selection:Opponent paint attempts: 46% (down from 50%)Opponent paint FG%: 54.5% (down from 58%)Opponent 3PT FG%: 32.5% (2nd best in the NBA, down from 36.6%) Defensive Scheme:The Lakers haven’t altered their defensive structure but have excelled at limiting dribble penetrationOpponents have taken more contested jumpers instead of getting easy shots at the rim. While some of their success may be due to opponents missing open shots, their ability to contest drives and force tougher looks has been a game-changer.2. Defensive Effort and Personnel UpgradesBeyond tactical adjustments, the Lakers have simply been working harder and making smarter rotations on defense.A prime example came in their March 6 win over the Knicks, where they shut down New York’s top-five offense after halftime. Gabe Vincent excelled at fighting through screens, while Luka Doncic, Jaxson Hayes, and LeBron James executed defensive switches flawlessly to stifle Jalen Brunson and his teammates. Key Defensive Personnel AdditionsDorian Finney-Smith – A key acquisition who adds size, versatility, and defensive IQJaxson Hayes – Provides rim protection and defensive energyGabe Vincent – His return to health has strengthened the Lakers’ perimeter defense Defensive Rating With Key Defenders on the FloorWhen at least two of Finney-Smith, Hayes, and Vincent are on the court, the Lakers allow just 105.6 points per 100 possesions—an elite defensive mark.3. Three Playmakers Are Better Than TwoLuka Doncic has transformed the Lakers’ offense, but the key to their success has been having multiple creators on the floor. With Doncic, Austin Reaves, and LeBron James all capable of running the offense, defenses can no longer key in on just one player. Lakers’ Primary Playmakers (Time of Possession Per Game)Luka Doncic – 6.9 minutesAustin Reaves – 5.3 minutesLeBron James – 5.2 minutes Why Three Playmakers Matter for the Los Angeles LakersConstant offensive pressure – The Lakers can keep at least two elite ball-handlers on the court at all timesDefenses can’t overload – Opponents struggle to focus on just one creator, leading to better shot opportunitiesSeamless ball movement – Successive actions involving all three players create open looks. A prime example of this strategy was seen in the Lakers’ game against Minnesota, where Doncic initiated the play, Reaves made the extra pass, and Finney-Smith finished with a wide-open three. 4. Size, Home Dominance, and Clutch Play 1192299411. The Lakers Still Have Size Even after trading Anthony Davis for Doncic, the Lakers remain one of the biggest teams in the NBA.Their primary lineup includes four players 6'8\" or taller, with Gabe Vincent (6’2”) being the only rotation player under 6’5”This allows them to dominate matchups against smaller teams while still maintaining offensive versatility. 2. Elite Home RecordThe Lakers have been dominant at home, winning 15 of their last 16 games at Crypto.com Arena. However, they have struggled on the road, with the NBA's biggest home-road differential in winning percentage. Location Record Win % Home 27-7 79.4% Away 15-18 45.5% 3. Clutch PerformanceDespite their eighth-best point differential, the Lakers’ 42-25 record is a result of clutch winsThey have the NBA’s fifth-best clutch record (20-13), thriving in close gamesHowever, they have lost their last three clutch games, showing an area for improvement 4. Success Against Elite TeamsThe Lakers have the fourth-best record (19-14) against teams over .500.They won 11 straight games against winning teams before losing to Boston, Milwaukee, and Denver—all without LeBron James.Nine of their final 15 games are against teams with winning records, offering more opportunities to prove their contender status. The Lakers’ transformation has put them in a prime position heading into the playoffs. With an elite defense, improved depth, and multiple playmakers, they have the tools to compete for an NBA championship.Also read: NBA Offseason Rumors: Los Angeles Lakers might sign 6-foot-10 Atlanta Hawks center to support LeBron James and Luka Doncic As they prepare for their final 15 games, including key matchups against the Nuggets and Bucks, Los Angeles has a chance to solidify itself as a top contender. If they can maintain their defensive intensity, improve their road play, and continue their clutch success, the Lakers will be a serious threat in the Western Conference.(H/t: John Schuhmann of NBA)
